review_title: Salem Hospital is a fine place to work.
pros: Health services are never going to go away, and Salem Hospital is committed to maintaining their competence in the field. While their Information Services department has some old parts to it, they are really committed to using new technologies and successfully phasing out old ones. The atmosphere was nice and the department had a good camaraderie. Really, the best reason to work for a hospital is that it is an area of work where you really are making a difference in people's lives. The work that you do saves and or makes people's lives better. Also, due to the bureaucratic nature of the company, it's a fairly stable career.
cons:
It is in Salem Oregon. Salem is not exactly the best place to live.

Their internal software systems are a mess in some places. Which is one of the consequences of trying to modernize the internal information systems. Still though, it can be a pain in the ass trying to navigate some disparate systems during the course of your work.

The people are nice enough, though the majority of employees are technologically illiterate and don't understand that Information Services has not a lot to do with whether or not your email account got a virus. Still, the doctors are nice enough to work with.

pros: The gals working at the various cafes are a pleasure to deal with.  Pinnacle of customer service.
cons: It's a cult with frosting.  You go through a period where they try to brow beat you into compliance with things that don't make sense.  They don't understand how to use people, and the bias against people without a bachelors is a real thing.  They just won't say it to your face, it's how you're treated...like you simply don't matter.  You'll be given the work nobody else wants to do because of this.  HR won't help you, they say they will but then stab you in the back.  Corporate Integrity (a department) won't help you if HR refuses to help you.  Upper management will just say "that hasn't been my experience" - well, of course not, you're sitting in a fancy office all day.  Parking is and will continue to be a nightmare that won't be fixed, they don't support remote work, they require the old school "be here at 8AM" culture that nobody else does, they misuse and abuse Lean as an excuse to keep people busy, and the benefits are gated behind red tape: furloughs to force you to use PTO, inability to access everything when you're new, etc etc.  And don't get sick, or deities help you.

pros: Hard working friendly compassionate staff
cons: Management is inadequate from assistant nurse managers up

pros: Pay. Staff. Beautiful campus located in good location within Salem.
cons:
Management within IS are ineffective and spend too much time in meetings and enforcing LEAN fundamentals in the daily work. They don’t understand the amount of work they create on some staff and allow other staff to do very little. Horrible execution when it comes to completing projects! Sustain and operate is reactive, causing excessive stress on staff to maintain. LEAN! LEAN! LEAN! Makes too much emphasis on making charts, false metrics, silly wall art to show bogus results. So called “Test of change” is a cover up to excuse lack of thought before implementing a “great idea”, 

Be prepared to feel stressed more than normal, under appreciated, overworked and ignored. Have little sense of purpose and ownership to the work. Inequality of workload. It’s 0300 as I write this review if that tells you anything. It shouldn’t be this easy to have so much to dislike about a company, but it’s the environment in IS that creates the response.

pros:
-Awesome coworkers
-Great work environment
-Great amount of hours
-Awesome benefits
-Great supervisor
cons: Management is horrible, they seem to like the fact that every single one of their employees must abide by the "Lean Rules" of Kaizen basics. To be honest, I couldn't care less about those concepts - they are a waste of time and make everybody's job harder. Why can't I just come to work and finish my shift without having to think about how I can improve the company? I wasn't hired to be the organization's next President! That's not my job and to be frank leadership should be taking more advice from their bottom line workers instead of looking at their fancy numbers on charts - numbers aren't going to tell you anything! Rather than bash your workers with statistical facts, I would prefer you hear their stories and what they have to say.

review_title: loyalty to supervisors valued above competence and caring for patients first
pros:

cons:
High turnover of talented employees, TROUBLEMAKERS REMAIN
Fears of unionization are warranted due to HR practices - not even handed or good listeners
Politically competitive and unhealthy work environment due to incompetent Supervisory personnel playing favorites and 'snitches' i.e. Supervisors are the problem not the solution (incompetence).
Lazy and trouble-making employees are favored above committed, competent, hard workers who speak up on behalf of the hospital patient's.

pros: Pay and benefits are OK. Clinical staff are generally decent
cons: IS has the worst culture run by arrogant leaders hired from outside industries. They have no idea what they're talking about and no insight for the industry. Worse, they dictate without consulting or listening to their staff. We used to have employee surveys but when leaders continued to score terribly, they did away with them. The VP has a few friends he's hired and treats them better than other leaders. If you're not a "yes man" and question anything in leadership they force you out or eliminate your job. The apps director is from a bookstore and knows very little. He listens to no one and makes a fool of himself frequently as he arrogantly dictates constant changes. Staff are miserable and afraid to speak up because the leadership team is vindictive and will come after you, despite an HR anti retaliation policy. There's no direction or communication and the turnover rates are very high. They talk a good game, but they're deceptive. The best people leave or get fired, stay away unless it's a quick stepping stone for you.

pros: Excellent salary and benefits; worked with some very talented and good-hearted professionals and leaders; very good patient outcomes; many skilled, highly qualified, compassionate front-line employees
cons: Salem Health’s Darwinistic work environment fosters a dog-eat-dog competitiveness and high turnover at manager and director level. The leadership team frequently uses “restructuring” for personal reasons to move high-performing leaders or professionals out of the organization. Senior executives maintain a veneer of transparency that makes it harder to see machinations for personal enrichment or power. Smart, highly qualified professionals who care about people and the community get out as soon as they can. I've since seen many Salem Health refugees at my current, highly recommended employer, Providence Health & Services.

pros: Everyone in the organization is clearly committed to the patient.  Transparent culture.  Competitive pay and benefits.  Service excellence and quality focused.  This organization has come so far in the past decade in terms of quality and service. Award after award after award...well deserved.  Committed employees.  This would be my first choice to get health care.
cons: Although fiscally strong, the continued pressure to reduce waste and save more money is relentless.  This is not the leadership's fault, but rather an indication of what's happening throughout the industry...it's Salem's attempt at getting ahead of the problem, which is noble.  But sometimes the relentless focus here takes it's toll on those in the organization who are trying to manage and effectively implement change.  After a while, it takes it's toll.  Again, not unique to this organization...going on everywhere in healthcare.

pros: Great pay and benefits. Nice campus.
cons:
The leadership of IS is incompetent and rarely seeks the advice of its lower employees when making decisions. Decisions are made on the basis of what other leaders feel is a good idea. Then, those decisions rarely transpire into a well thought-out plan with a strategy and long-term road map.

Many many surveys have been filled out over the years by all IS employees. The results of these surveys are VERY RARELY ever shared. What is shared is "how lean we are" and other silly fake money type gimmicks. If they really wanted to save money, they would find ways to cause employees to stop leaving so much. 

Nobody feels comfortable speaking up in the current environment where it is so easy to get blacklisted and pushed out.

pros: Salem Hospital was good to me from the time I started as a candy stripper at 13. SH trained me to be a CNA at 17. I went to 4 years of nursing school. Graduated and returned to S.H. I worked there the majority of my long career. But in 2009 all the nurses were feeling un-easy abt possible lay offs. It had been rumoured in the past abt getting rid of older nurses. Which of course was adammately denied by administration. I felt paranoid and was being taken advantage of by younger staff. Assistant managers were talking with there buddies on their cigarette breaks abt other staff members. Rumors were flying. I began to notice I was not getting the recognition I deserved. I felt very vulnerable and fearful that these girls were setting me up for a fall. I was always a hard worker. Rarely had free time. Rarely took breaks. Put my pts first. My younger coworkers had time to sit and socialize and gossip. I felt compassion was missing in alot of the patients care. Many nurses just did what they had too to get done. I always had good evaluations and I was very proud to be a part of the SH nursing team. To this day I have pain in my heart for how I was treated. I went into nursing to help people. That was God's Gift to me. See I spent a good share of my child hood in a hospital. I knew what it was like to feel pain .  God gave me a purpose in living. S H destroyed my self esteem and my sense of worthiness.
cons: If you were not in the popular bunch of staff members...you sometimes got mistreated or taken advantage of. I was guiet and a hard worker. I was an easy target for difficult assignments that other nurses didnt want. I must stress that this was not always the case. Things didnt really start getting difficult untill after abt 2001.
